title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: begin simple example confirmatory factor analysis (CFA), using theminorbsem() function fit model. minorbsem package contains built-dataset called HS, part classic Holzinger-Swineford dataset. dataset used many papers books CFA. dataset consists mental ability test scores seventh eighth grade children two different schools (Pasteur Grant-White). version dataset (obtained lavaan, Rosseel (2012)), 9 original 26 tests included. begin loading package: first six lines dataset:

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: scale data important setting priors model parameters. default priors models fit minorbsem reasonable variables standard deviations close 1. reason, first check standard deviations relevant variables analysis: variables standard deviations close 1, can move forward data . Otherwise, recommend re-scaling variables.1

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: model syntax lavaan-style: model assumes three latent variables (factors): visual, verbal, speed. visual factor indicators: x1, x2, x3; verbal factor indicators: x4, x5, x6; speed factor indicators: x7, x8, x9.
code: syntax_basic <- " Visual =~ x1 + x2 + x3 Verbal =~ x4 + x5 + x6 Speed =~ x7 + x8 + x9"

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: run analysis using minorbsem() function. default, function assumes minor factors influence covariance variables. minorbsem prints iterations Stan – show iterations reader knows expect.

text: PPP. first section results contains parameters help assess global model fit. “PPP” posterior predictive p-value form described Muthén Asparouhov (2012), akin χ2\chi^2 test standard SEMs. conventional prefer values .05 .10. , PPP = .382 indicating good-fitting model. Desirable PPP-values expected default minorbsem package accounts model misspecification – alternatively stated: PPP-values .05 imply absence misfit informative default. report PPP since minorbsem also able fit Bayesian SEMs account misspecification, e.g. minorbsem(..., method = "none"). RMSE. root mean square error standardized residual covariances (SRCs) communicates typical size SRCs. One may also interpret metric standard deviation SRCs 95% SRCs lying within 2 RMSE values 0. example, RMSE = 0.063 can expect SRCs greater 0.10, suggesting large SRCs (Maydeu-Olivares 2017). Large SRCs challenge notion model misspecification due influence minor factors – influences large, factors “minor”? possible hypothesized structure incorrect, minor factors significant effects.

code: syntax_bifactor <- paste0(   "G =~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 + x5 + x6 + x7 + x8 + x9", "\n",   syntax_basic ) writeLines(syntax_bifactor) ## G =~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 + x5 + x6 + x7 + x8 + x9 ##  ## Visual =~ x1 + x2 + x3 ## Verbal =~ x4 + x5 + x6 ## Speed =~ x7 + x8 + x9

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: call minorbsem() needs form: minorbsem(..., orthogonal = TRUE) ensure factors orthogonal: Compared basic CFA model, RMSE drops .063 .028, suggesting much better fitting model. items load 90% intervals excluding 0 general factor, except x7. Additionally, x1 – x3 load confusingly specific factor, x4 – x9 load strongly specific factors especially compared general factor loadings. pattern factor loadings provide little support bifactor structure.

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
code: syntax_bifactor_cons <- paste0(   "G =~ x1 + x2 + x3 + x4 + x5 + x6 + x7 + x8 + x9", "\n",   "Visual =~ a * x1 + a * x2 + a * x3   Verbal =~ b * x4 + b * x5 + b * x6   Speed =~ c * x7 + c * x8 + c * x9" )

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: RMSE increased since model constrained. pattern results parameter constraints imposed suggest general factor mostly reflects items x1 – x3, items strongly reflecting specific factors. results suggest limited applicability bifactor model data.

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: final model, return original basic CFA relax simple structure. Unlike Muthén Asparouhov (2012) using small-variance priors, minorbsem using global-local prior (Uanhoro 2024). Precisely, approach assumes cross-loadings indeed zero outlier non-zero cross loadings.

title: Confirmatory Factor Analysis
text: call minorbsem() needs form: minorbsem(..., simple_struc = FALSE) effect minor factors small, RMSE = 0.024. original hypothesized loadings maintain relation hypothesized factors. cross-loadings, relation visual factor x9 non-trivial, close 0. Additionally, interfactor correlations reduced original basic CFA, suggesting forcing cross-loadings zero artificially inflated interfactor correlations (Ferrando Lorenzo-Seva 2000).

title: Multiple Indicators and Multiple Causes (MIMIC) Model
text: model syntax lavaan-style. first syntax, one predictor age. model defines Visual latent factor three observed variables x1, x2 x3, specifies regression Visual fageyr.fageyr latent variable created represent observed year variable, ageyr. last line syntax fixes residual variance ageyr 0 ensure variance ageyr contained within fageyr, .e. fageyr ageyr.

title: Multiple Indicators and Multiple Causes (MIMIC) Model
text: PPP. first section results contains parameters help assess global model fit. “PPP” posterior predictive p-value form described Muthén Asparouhov (2012), akin χ2\chi^2 test standard SEMs. conventional prefer values .05 .10. , PPP = .382 indicating good-fitting model. Desirable PPP-values expected default minorbsem package accounts model misspecification – alternatively stated: PPP-values .05 imply absence misfit informative default. report PPP since minorbsem also able fit Bayesian SEMs account misspecification, e.g. minorbsem(..., method = "none"). RMSE. root mean square error standardized residual covariances (SRCs) communicates typical size SRCs. One may also interpret metric standard deviation SRCs 95% SRCs lying within 2 RMSE values 0. example, RMSE = 0.063 can expect SRCs greater 0.10, suggesting large SRCs (Maydeu-Olivares 2017). Large SRCs challenge notion model misspecification due influence minor factors – influences large, factors “minor”? possible hypothesized structure incorrect, minor factors significant effects.

Assuming η=20\eta = 20, Beta(20.5, 20.5). distributions visualized .  see larger values lkj_shape can used constrain interfactor correlations.

text: Goals Permitted models supported data types Installation reasonably complete demonstration Different methods capture influence minor factors Relax simple structure Contributions encouraged Citations

title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
text: Structural equation models (SEMs) rarely reject null hypothesis model misspecification. One explanation problem covariance structures influenced major factors can hypothesize minor factors predict -priori, e.g. MacCallum Tucker (1991).

title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
text: goal minorbsem facilitate fitting Bayesian SEMs estimate influence minor factors covariance matrix, following approach Uanhoro (2023). Briefly, method estimates residual covariances priors shrink towards zero, model returns magnitude influence minor factors. package also allows set priors substantive model parameters directly. Importantly, prior distributions assume latent variables total variance 1, even latent regression models.

what: Permitted models and supported data types
title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
text: package able fit variety model configurations: CFA, allowing automatically estimated penalized cross-loadings observed variables structural model must represented single-indicator latent variable error variance observed variable constrained 0 package also able analyze correlation structures using methods Archakov Hansen (2021). includes polychoric correlation matrices long asymptotic variance matrix provided. relevant paper review Structural Equation Modeling. package support fitting multi-group multilevel models. See bayesianmasem package multi-group factor analysis via meta-analysis methods.

title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
text: minorbsem hosted GitHub, need remotes package install . also need install cmdstanr package CmdStan order use Stan. Instructions:
code: install.packages("remotes")  # install remotes  # next install cmdstanr and CmdStan: install.packages(   "cmdstanr",   repos = c("https://mc-stan.org/r-packages/", getOption("repos")) ) cmdstanr::check_cmdstan_toolchain(fix = TRUE) cmdstanr::install_cmdstan()  # Then finally minorbsem: remotes::install_github("jamesuanhoro/minorbsem")

title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
code: library(minorbsem) # Basic Holzinger-Swineford model syntax_1 <- " F1 =~ x1 + x2 + x3 F2 =~ x4 + x5 + x6 F3 =~ x7 + x8 + x9" # Expect a summary table output fit_1 <- minorbsem(syntax_1, HS)  # Save output table to html file, see: ?pretty_print_summary for more options pretty_print_summary(fit_1, save_html = "baseline_model.html")  # Histogram of parameters, see: ?parameter_hist for arguments parameter_hist(fit_1)  # Traceplot of parameters, see: ?parameter_trace for arguments parameter_trace(fit_1)  # Examine all standardized residual covariances plot_residuals(fit_1) plot_residuals(fit_1, type = "range")

what: Different methods to capture the influence of minor factors
title: Fit Bayesian structural equation models under the assumption that model misspecification is random.
text: Default method method = "normal" assuming standardized residual covariances average 0 vary 0 continuous fashion.
code: # Fit same model as above but use global-local prior to estimate # minor factor influences fit_gdp <- minorbsem(syntax_1, HS, method = "GDP") plot_residuals(fit_gdp) parameter_hist(fit_gdp) parameter_trace(fit_gdp)  # Ignoring minor factor influences fit_none <- minorbsem(syntax_1, HS, method = "none") parameter_hist(fit_none) parameter_trace(fit_none)  # Error!!!: Plotting residuals will give an error message # since minor factor influences are assumed null plot_residuals(fit_none)

code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ fit <- minorbsem("F1 =~ x1 + x2 + x3                   F2 =~ x4 + x5 + x6                   F3 =~ x7 + x8 + x9", HS) res_net <- compute_residual_network(fit) p_corr_df <- posterior::summarise_draws(res_net) n_items <- sqrt(nrow(p_corr_df)) p_corr_mat <- matrix(p_corr_df$mean, n_items) p_corr_mat qgraph::qgraph(p_corr_mat, layout = "spring")  # Complete Gaussian graphical model via a unidimensional model # with all loadings set to zero. fit <- minorbsem(paste0("F =~ ", paste0("0 * x", 1:9, collapse = " + ")), HS) res_net <- compute_residual_network(fit) p_corr_df <- posterior::summarise_draws(res_net) n_items <- sqrt(nrow(p_corr_df)) p_corr_mat <- matrix(p_corr_df$mean, n_items) p_corr_mat qgraph::qgraph(p_corr_mat, layout = "spring") } # }

FALSE (default), fits model given user inputs.

title: Fit Bayesian SEMs with minor factors assumed — minorbsem
text: object mbsem-class

title: Fit Bayesian SEMs with minor factors assumed — minorbsem
text: CFAs assume standardized factors. Latent variable regression models print results standardized loadings. different methods estimating models package: normal: belief minor factor influences average zero continuous deviations away zero (Uanhoro 2023) . lasso: belief minor factor influences largely zero small number non-zero residual covariances. logistic: similar belief normal readily accomodates extreme outliers. GDP: mimic global-local approach, .e. attempt shrink near 0 residual covariances 0 minimal shrinking larger residual covariances (Armagan et al. 2013) . WB: model covariance matrix hierarchically assumptions adventitiuous error (Wu Browne 2015) ; allow computation casewise log-likelihoods LOO-CV. WB-cond: WB estimates "population covariance matrix", allowing computation casewise log-likelihoods LOO-CV. WW: variation WB-cond, assumes population covariance matrix Wishart opposed inverse-Wishart; none: intending ignore influence minor factors. WB-cond WW equivalent correlation structure analysis.

title: Fit Bayesian SEMs with minor factors assumed — minorbsem
text: Archakov , Hansen PR (2021). “New Parametrization Correlation Matrices.” Econometrica, 89(4), 1699–1715. ISSN 1468-0262, doi:10.3982/ECTA16910 , https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.3982/ECTA16910. Armagan , Dunson DB, Lee J (2013). “Generalized double Pareto shrinkage.” Statistica Sinica, 23(1), 119–143. ISSN 1017-0405, https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3903426/. Uanhoro JO (2023). “Modeling Misspecification Parameter Bayesian Structural Equation Models.” Educational Psychological Measurement, 0(0), 00131644231165306. ISSN 0013-1644, doi:10.1177/00131644231165306 , https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/00131644231165306. Wu H, Browne MW (2015). “Quantifying Adventitious Error Covariance Structure Random Effect.” Psychometrika, 80(3), 571–600. ISSN 1860-0980, doi:10.1007/s11336-015-9451-3 .

title: Fit Bayesian SEMs with minor factors assumed — minorbsem
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ mod_cfa <- minorbsem(   "# latent variable definitions   F1 =~ x1 + x2 + x3   F2 =~ x4 + x5 + x6   F3 =~ x7 + x8 + x9", HS ) new_pd <- PD apply(PD, 2, sd) # first 8 variables have relatively large SDs new_pd[, 1:8] <- new_pd[, 1:8] / 3 # move SDs closer to 1 mod_sem <- minorbsem(   "# latent variable definitions   ind60 =~ x1 + x2 + x3   dem60 =~ y1 + y2 + y3 + y4   dem65 =~ y5 + y6 + y7 + y8   # latent regressions   dem60 ~ ind60   dem65 ~ ind60 + dem60", new_pd ) mod_dl <- minorbsem(   "# latent variable definitions   F1 =~ x1 + x2 + x3   F2 =~ x4 + x5 + x6   F3 =~ x7 + x8 + x9", HS,   ret_data_list = TRUE ) mod_dl$load_est # prior mean for loadings mod_dl$load_se # prior sd for loadings mod_dl$load_se[9, 3] <- .75 # set prior SD for F3 =~ x9 to .75 # fit model with updated prior mod <- minorbsem(data_list = mod_dl) } # }

Residual plots lasso GDP methods now show mode estimate (modeest::hsm()) instead median, since methods shrink mode 0. Added function ci_results() conditional independence parameters. Completed path analysis tests.
